<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of parse_cookie_header:
```c
static enum _MHD_ParseCookie
parse_cookie_header (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  const char *hdr;
  size_t hdr_len;
  char *cpy;
  size_t i;
  enum _MHD_ParseCookie parse_res;
  struct MHD_HTTP_Req_Header *const saved_tail =
    connection->rq.headers_received_tail;
  const bool allow_partially_correct_cookie =
    (1 >= connection->daemon->client_discipline);

  if (MHD_NO ==
      MHD_lookup_connection_value_n (connection,
                                     MHD_HEADER_KIND,
                                     MHD_HTTP_HEADER_COOKIE,
                                     MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (
                                       MHD_HTTP_HEADER_COOKIE),
                                     &hdr,
                                     &hdr_len))
    return MHD_PARSE_COOKIE_OK;
  if (0 == hdr_len)
    return MHD_PARSE_COOKIE_OK;

  cpy = MHD_connection_alloc_memory_ (connection,
                                      hdr_len + 1);
  if (NULL == cpy)
    parse_res = MHD_PARSE_COOKIE_NO_MEMORY;
  else
  {
    memcpy (cpy,
            hdr,
            hdr_len);
    cpy[hdr_len] = '\0';

    i = 0;
    /* Skip all initial whitespaces */
    while (i < hdr_len && (' ' == cpy[i] || '\t' == cpy[i]))
      i++;

    parse_res = parse_cookies_string (cpy + i, hdr_len - i, connection);
  }

  switch (parse_res)
  {
  case MHD_PARSE_COOKIE_OK:
    break;
  case MHD_PARSE_COOKIE_OK_LAX:
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    if (saved_tail != connection->rq.headers_received_tail)
      MHD_DLOG (connection->daemon,
                _ ("The Cookie header has been parsed, but it is not fully "
                   "compliant with the standard.\n"));
#endif /* HAVE_MESSAGES */
    break;
  case MHD_PARSE_COOKIE_MALFORMED:
    if (saved_tail != connection->rq.headers_received_tail)
    {
      if (! allow_partially_correct_cookie)
      {
        /* Remove extracted values from partially broken cookie */
        /* Memory remains allocated until the end of the request processing */
        connection->rq.headers_received_tail = saved_tail;
        saved_tail->next = NULL;
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
        MHD_DLOG (connection->daemon,
                  _ ("The Cookie header has been ignored as it contains "
                     "malformed data.\n"));
#endif /* HAVE_MESSAGES */
      }
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
      else
        MHD_DLOG (connection->daemon,
                  _ ("The Cookie header has been only partially parsed as it "
                     "contains malformed data.\n"));
#endif /* HAVE_MESSAGES */
    }
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    else
      MHD_DLOG (connection->daemon,
                _ ("The Cookie header has malformed data.\n"));
#endif /* HAVE_MESSAGES */
    break;
  case MHD_PARSE_COOKIE_NO_MEMORY:
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    MHD_DLOG (connection->daemon,
              _ ("Not enough memory in the connection pool to "
                 "parse client cookies!\n"));
#endif /* HAVE_MESSAGES */
    break;
  default:
    mhd_assert (0);
    break;
  }
#ifndef HAVE_MESSAGES
  (void) saved_tail; /* Mute compiler warning */
#endif /* ! HAVE_MESSAGES */

  return parse_res;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no obvious invariant controlling expressions of loops or selection statements except for the use of the local const variable allow_partially_correct_cookie as a controlling expression. Rationale for not flagging other control expressions:

- while (i < hdr_len && (' ' == cpy[i] || '\t' == cpy[i])): the condition depends on i, hdr_len and cpy[] and i is modified in the loop, so the controlling expression is not invariant.

- if (MHD_NO == MHD_lookup_connection_value_n(...)) and if (0 == hdr_len): both depend on runtime results (lookup result and hdr_len) and are not compile-time or function-scope invariants.

- The switch (parse_res) is driven by parse_res which is set just prior based on runtime outcomes (allocation success or parse_cookies_string return). The value is not a compile-time constant and the switch is used to select handling of runtime parse results.

- Comparisons against saved_tail (saved_tail != connection->rq.headers_received_tail) depend on whether parse_cookies_string modified the list; that is runtime-mutated state, so the condition is not invariant.

- There are no do-while loops with a constant false controlling expression and no intentional infinite loops (while(1) or for(;;)) in the shown code; thus the two noted MISRA exceptions do not apply elsewhere here.

Why the reported fragments: allow_partially_correct_cookie is declared const and initialized once from connection->daemon->client_discipline. Because it cannot be modified later in the function, any subsequent if/else tests on that const become invariant during the remainder of the function execution; that pattern can trigger a MISRA Rule 14.3 concern and should be investigated to ensure the use of a const-initialized value as a controlling expression is acceptable in the project context.
